bestBHT.bht: The judgment to come is characterized by righteousness, as it will be a solemn judicial assize held upon all mankind at once, serving as a tangible display of the judicial authority vested in the Risen One. By referencing an altar to an Unknown God, Paul effectively captures the attention of his listeners, revealing that this God is the Creator of all things and all people, commanding repentance and declaring a day of reckoning when Jesus Christ will serve as the Judge. The resurrection of Jesus Christ serves as undeniable proof of the possibility of a general resurrection for all.

Henry Alford: Righteousness is the character of the judgment—the element of which it shall consist.
As the thing asserted was hardly credible, he gives a distinguished proof of it.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Such language beyond doubt teaches that the judgment will, in its essence, be a solemn judicial assize held upon all mankind at once."
Aptly is this uttered on the Areopagus, the seat of judgment
The most patent evidence to mankind at large of the judicial authority with which the Risen One is clothed.
Albert Barnes: They must be judged; and if they are not penitent and pardoned, they must be condemned.
Judge the world - The whole world - Jews and Gentiles.
God confirmed the truth of his declarations by raising him from the dead, or gave his sanction to what the Lord Jesus had said.
John Calvin: Therefore, let us remember that the doctrine of repentance doth then take place, when men, who would naturally desire to flatter themselves, are awaked with fear of God’s judgment and that fearful judgment is set before them, which they may neither despise nor escape.

Neither is this added in vain, in righteousness, or righteously. For though all men in the world confess that God is a just Judge, yet we see how they, for the most part, pamper and flatter themselves; for they will not suffer God to demand an account farther than their knowledge and understanding doth reach.

The will of God alone ought to be so reverenced among us, that every man for himself subscribe to his decrees without delay. Because the cloak and color of ignorance useth oftentimes to be objected, therefore Paul saith plainly, that Christ was by his resurrection openly showed to be the Judge of the world, and that that was revealed to the eyes of men, which God had before determined with himself concerning him.
Philip Schaff: Because he hath appointed a day in the which he will Judge the world in righteousness."
The resurrection of Jesus Christ is mentioned as showing the possibility of a general resurrection of all men from the dead.

They felt, did these Epicurean and Stoic teachers, that if the single instance of Christ’s resurrection was admitted or even allowed to be spoken of before such an assembly as that of the powerful Areopagites, the possibility of rising from the dead would be in a way conceded, and the teaching of these famous schools would be shown to be false.
Archibald T. Robertson: God did set the day in his counsel and he will fulfil it in his own time.

He skilfully caught their attention by reference to an altar to an Unknown God whom he interprets to be the Creator of all things and all men who overrules the whole world and who now commands repentance of all and has revealed his will about a day of reckoning when Jesus Christ will be Judge.
Note this old use of πιστις as conviction or ground of confidence (Hebrews 11:1) like a note or title-deed, a conviction resting on solid basis of fact.
John Gill: The day of judgment is fixed by God in his eternal purposes, and is sure and certain, and will come, though it is not known by men or angels.

The whole world will be judged, and every individual in it, good and bad, righteous and wicked; and this judgment will be a righteous one; it will proceed according to the strict rules of justice and equity.
Christ...being the person God had from all eternity ordained, and in time had signified, should have all judgment committed to him, and by whom the last judgment shall be managed and transacted.
John Wesley: He hath appointed a day in which he will judge the world."
By the man - So he speaks, suiting himself to the capacity of his hearers."
God raising Jesus demonstrated hereby, that he was to be the glorious Judge of all.

bhtAttempts.bht: The judgment spoken of in Acts 17:31 is characterized by righteousness. This judgment is a solemn judicial assize held upon all mankind at once, a display of the judicial authority with which the Risen One is clothed. Paul skillfully caught their attention by referencing an altar to an Unknown God and interpreting this God as the Creator of all things and all men who commands repentance from everyone, revealing His will about a day of reckoning when Jesus Christ will be Judge. The resurrection of Jesus Christ is mentioned as showing the possibility of a general resurrection of all men from the dead, confirming the truth of His declarations. This judgment, appointed by God Himself, will be righteous, and every individual in the whole world, good and bad, will be judged according to the strict rules of justice and equity by Christ, the glorious Judge.

The judgment described in the given verse will be characterized by righteousness, as it is a solemn judicial assize held on all mankind at once. This judgment showcases the judicial authority vested in the Risen One. The apostle Paul seizes the attention of his audience by referencing an altar dedicated to an Unknown God, which he explains to be the Creator of all things and men. By His resurrection, Jesus demonstrates the possibility of a general resurrection, affirming the truth of His teachings. This appointed day of judgment, managed by Christ, will be a righteous one, where every individual in the world will face judgment based on justice and equity.

The upcoming judgment, spoken of with a sense of conviction and credibility, will be a solemn judicial assize held upon all mankind, a powerful manifestation of the ruling authority bestowed upon the Risen One. The apostle Paul strategically captures the attention of his audience by drawing their focus to an altar dedicated to an Unknown God, whom he astutely interprets to be the Creator and sovereign ruler over all. Through the resurrection of Jesus Christ, the possibility of a general resurrection for all humanity is demonstrated, validating the truth of His teachings. This divinely appointed day of judgment, embodying righteousness and justice, will be presided over by Christ, the Judge of the world.

The judgment to come is characterized by righteousness, as it will be a solemn judicial assize held upon all mankind at once, serving as a tangible display of the judicial authority vested in the Risen One. By referencing an altar to an Unknown God, Paul effectively captures the attention of his listeners, revealing that this God is the Creator of all things and all people, commanding repentance and declaring a day of reckoning when Jesus Christ will serve as the Judge. The resurrection of Jesus Christ serves as undeniable proof of the possibility of a general resurrection for all.

The impending judgment, mentioned in Acts 17:31, is described as a solemn judicial assize held on all mankind, affirming the righteous character of this divine judgment. The Apostle Paul expertly catches the attention of his listeners by referencing an altar to an Unknown God and interpreting this deity as the Creator of all things and all people—a God who commands repentance and announces a forthcoming day of reckoning with Jesus Christ as the Judge. The resurrection of Jesus serves as a compelling evidence for the possibility of a general resurrection for all.
